text: Hi, my name is Dan Slater.

I'm the worldwide head of the
Culture of Innovation

program and part of AWS's Innovation
and Transformation
organization.

I have been with Amazon since
2005, and in my time here,

I've seen a lot of change
as Amazon has scaled to the scope
and size that it is today.

But one thing that hasn't
changed is Amazon's culture

and how we approach organizing
for innovation.

Today, I'd like to share some
deeper insights into Amazon's

culture of innovation
and the learnings we've incorporated

from our approach as we've
scaled.

Amazon's approach to innovation
is driven by what we call a "Day
1" mentality.

This term comes from Jeff Bezos's
Letter to Shareholders

in Amazon's first Annual Report
in 1997, a letter that we reprint

with every annual report we've
released since.

In this letter, Jeff outlines
the fundamental measures

of Amazon's success, relentlessly
obsessing over customers,

empowering each and every one
of Amazon builders to make high-quality

and high-velocity decisions
that create constant long-term

value for customers, and making
many bold bets.

"This is Day 1 for the Internet,"
Bezos wrote, "and, if we execute

well, for Amazon.com."
Amazon's approach to innovating

for customers is inspired
by this "Day 1" mentality.

We seek to ensure that customers
and their needs are at the center
of everything that we do.

We want to ceaselessly
experiment to surprise and delight
our customers.

And we want to maintain
a long-term view, being patient

with the bold and disruptive
experiments that we undertake,

with constant inspection
and iteration based on the learnings
obtained along the way.

This approach has been consistent
since Amazon's literal Day 1,
until today.

And as Amazon grew, we wanted
to ensure we maintained

the start-up energy of a "Day
1" mentality: being nimble

and agile, rapidly responding
to customers' needs and inventing

on their behalf, and remaining
scrappy to move with the speed
that customers demand and deserve.

Creating and maintaining
this "Day 1" culture is easier
when your company is smaller.

Executive leaders can model
corporate values directly

to employees and are involved
in many if not all strategic
decisions.

However, and you may have experienced
this already in your own company,

it all gets harder to do as the
company scales.

As Amazon has scaled across
over 1.5 million employees

and across myriad lines of business,
from ecommerce to robust AWS

Cloud services to hardware
devices, such as the Kindle

and Echo, into Prime Video
and original content through

Amazon Studios to consumables,
like Amazon Fresh, and even

physical stores, like Amazon
Go and Whole Foods.

Maintaining that "Day 1" culture
becomes much harder to do and
much harder to keep consistent.

We have to be vigilant every
day about staving off a "Day 2" mentality,

one that brings stasis and bureaucracy
to decision-making

focus instead of remaining
fast-paced, innovative,
and disruptive.

There can be many signs that
a company is moving into a "Day

2" mentality, and a few are listed
here.

For example, decisions
become tougher, and slower,

to make across a much larger
number of distributed
stakeholders.

There is a danger of becoming
more risk-averse and less tolerant

of failure in order to protect
the present business instead

of challenging your company's
builders to find new ways to meet

your customers' constantly
evolving needs.

You may find your organization
maybe is prioritizing

goals, and thus the behavior,
more on short-term business

targets instead of driving
long-term sustainable
customer value.

You might remain in the status
quo instead of encouraging

innovation and experimentation,
embracing the learning that

comes from failure along the
way and even reinventing

yourself in bold ways in order
to continue to innovate
for your customers.

Now, we are far from perfect
and have had to work hard to stave
off that "Day 2" mentality.

But the one thing I believe
that's really helped Amazon

retain our "Day 1" mentality
and our long-term focus on customers

is the structured approach
to innovation that we take,

which helps us surprise
and delight customers and invent
on their behalf.

And I'm happy to share that
structured approach with you
today.

Amazon's approach to innovation
relies on four interdependent

elements: Building that "Day 1" culture
to empower each and every employee

to innovate on behalf of their
customers.

Creating effective mechanisms
to support that innovative

culture, systematically
turning good intentions

into effective action with constant
inspection and iteration
along the way.

Leveraging a robust technology
architecture that enables

you to move quickly from idea
to experimentation
to global scale.

And creating organizational
structures that optimize

innovation and maintain
a "Day 1" culture, with laser-like
focus on your customers.

I will go over each of these
elements, starting with culture.
